<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 100.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 74, 126, 89]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 668, 530]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1}\right)\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67\times 10^{- 8}\mathrm{Wm}^{- 2}\mathrm{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 566, 168, 582]]<|/det|>
## Formulae

Doppler effect for sound waves

resistors in parallel

\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 163, 604, 182]]<|/det|>
\[e = 1.60\times 10^{-19}\mathrm{C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 194, 610, 214]]<|/det|>
\[1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \text{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 225, 610, 246]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{-27}\mathrm{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 255, 610, 275]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{-31}\mathrm{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 285, 628, 306]]<|/det|>
\[N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 317, 610, 336]]<|/det|>
\[R = 8.31\mathrm{~J~K}^{-1}\mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 348, 620, 368]]<|/det|>
\[k = 1.38\times 10^{-23}\mathrm{~J~K}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 380, 668, 400]]<|/det|>
\[G = 6.67\times 10^{-11}\mathrm{Nm}^2\mathrm{kg}^{-2}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 410, 635, 465]]<|/det|>
\[\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{-12}\mathrm{Fm}^{-1}\] \[(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{-1})\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 475, 615, 494]]<|/det|>
\[h = 6.63\times 10^{-34}\mathrm{Js}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 505, 665, 525]]<|/det|>
\[\sigma = 5.67\times 10^{-8}\mathrm{Wm}^{-2}\mathrm{K}^{-4}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 598, 561, 636]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 650, 530, 668]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 680, 520, 698]]<|/det|>
\[F = \rho gV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 710, 534, 747]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{\mathrm{s}}V}{V\pm V_{\mathrm{s}}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 759, 530, 778]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 790, 586, 810]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 820, 598, 855]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 81, 536, 100]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential \(\phi = - \frac{GM}{r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 123, 551, 144]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{p}} = - \frac{GMm}{r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 166, 568, 188]]<|/det|>
pressure of an ideal gas \(p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 203, 536, 221]]<|/det|>
simple harmonic motion \(a = - \omega^2 x\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 235, 560, 253]]<|/det|>
velocity of particle in s.h.m. \(v = v_0 \cos \omega t\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 252, 613, 280]]<|/det|>
\[v = \pm \omega \sqrt{(x_0^2 - x^2)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 293, 544, 316]]<|/det|>
electric potential \(V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 338, 544, 365]]<|/det|>
electrical potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{p}} = \frac{Qq}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 384, 599, 413]]<|/det|>
capacitors in series \(\frac{1}{C} = \frac{1}{C_1} + \frac{1}{C_2} + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 428, 584, 447]]<|/det|>
capacitors in parallel \(C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 467, 554, 488]]<|/det|>
discharge of a capacitor \(x = x_0 \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{t}{RC}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 510, 520, 535]]<|/det|>
Hall voltage \(V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 549, 559, 568]]<|/det|>
alternating current/voltage \(x = x_0 \sin \omega t\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 581, 539, 599]]<|/det|>
radioactive decay \(x = x_0 \mathrm{e}^{-\lambda t}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 616, 544, 644]]<|/det|>
decay constant \(\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 668, 574, 705]]<|/det|>
intensity reflection coefficient \(\frac{I_{\mathrm{R}}}{I_0} = \frac{(Z_1 - Z_2)^2}{(Z_1 + Z_2)^2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 720, 554, 739]]<|/det|>
Stefanâ€“Boltzmann law \(L = 4\pi \sigma r^2 T^4\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 758, 554, 785]]<|/det|>
Doppler redshift \(\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda} \approx \frac{\Delta f}{f} \approx \frac{v}{c}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 185, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 71, 472, 89]]<|/det|>
State Newton's law of gravitation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 102, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 163, 920, 181]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 194, 181, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 193, 920, 227]]<|/det|>
Use Newton's law of gravitation to show that the gravitational field strength \(g\) at a distance \(r\) away from a point mass \(M\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 234, 539, 262]]<|/det|>
\[g = \frac{GM}{r^2}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 399, 920, 416]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 428, 146, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 428, 722, 447]]<|/det|>
The Earth has a mass of \(5.98 \times 10^{24} \text{kg}\) and a radius of \(6.37 \times 10^{6} \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 444, 722, 463]]<|/det|>
The Moon has a mass of \(7.35 \times 10^{22} \text{kg}\) and a radius of \(1.74 \times 10^{6} \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 459, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
The Earth and the Moon can both be considered as point masses at their centres. Their centres are a distance of \(3.84 \times 10^{8} \text{m}\) apart.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 507, 181, 525]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 507, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
Show that the gravitational field strength at the surface of the Moon due to the mass of the Moon is \(1.62 \text{N} \text{kg}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 631, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 661, 181, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 661, 920, 694]]<|/det|>
Explain why there is a point X on the line between the centres of the Earth and the Moon where the resultant gravitational field strength due to the Earth and the Moon is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 710, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 764, 920, 781]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 769, 920, 787]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A sphere of mass \(1.6 \times 10^{- 10} \text{kg}\) has a charge of \(+0.27 \text{nC}\). The sphere is in a uniform electric field that acts vertically upwards, as shown in the side view in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 149, 826, 343]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 359, 532, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 920, 424]]<|/det|>
The force exerted on the sphere by the electric field causes the sphere to remain at a fixed vertical height in a horizontal plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 438, 920, 486]]<|/det|>
There is a uniform magnetic field in the region of the electric field. The sphere moves at a speed of \(0.78 \text{m s}^{-1}\) in the horizontal plane. The magnetic field causes the sphere to move in a circular path of radius \(3.4 \text{m}\), as shown in the view from above in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 526, 784, 803]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 820, 532, 838]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 646, 89]]<|/det|>
A fixed mass of an ideal gas is initially at a temperature of \(17^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 650, 104]]<|/det|>
The gas has a volume of \(0.24 \text{m}^3\) and a pressure of \(1.2 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 144, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 181, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 117, 494, 135]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by an ideal gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 240, 180, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 240, 448, 259]]<|/det|>
Calculate the amount \(n\) of gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 368, 920, 386]]<|/det|>
<form>n = ...................................................... mol [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 400, 146, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 717, 419]]<|/det|>
The gas undergoes three successive changes, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 432, 870, 755]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 774, 532, 792]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 804, 920, 838]]<|/det|>
The initial state is represented by point A. The gas is cooled at constant pressure to point B by the removal of \(48.0 \text{kJ}\) of thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 852, 598, 870]]<|/det|>
The gas is then heated at constant volume to point C.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 883, 920, 916]]<|/det|>
Finally, the gas expands at constant temperature back to its original pressure and volume at point A. During this expansion, the gas does \(31.6 \text{kJ}\) of work.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 813, 89]]<|/det|> Show that the magnitude of the work done during the change AB is \(19.2 \text{kJ}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 213, 920, 231]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 244, 181, 262]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 243, 920, 293]]<|/det|> Complete Table 3.1 to show the work done on the gas, the thermal energy supplied to the gas and the increase in internal energy of the gas, for each of the changes AB, BC and CA. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 306, 541, 323]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 845, 594]]<|/det|>
changework done on gas/kJthermal energy
supplied to gas/kJ		increase in internal energy of gas/kJ
AB-48.0
BC
CA-31.6
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 591, 920, 609]]<|/det|> [5] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 622, 920, 640]]<|/det|> [Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
A pendulum consists of a bob (small metal sphere) attached to the end of a piece of string. The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point. The bob oscillates with small oscillations about its equilibrium position, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[205, 129, 761, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 399, 591, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label> <label>(not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 432, 902, 450]]<|/det|>
The length \(L\) of the pendulum, measured from the fixed point to the centre of the bob, is \(1.24 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 462, 920, 496]]<|/det|>
The acceleration \(a\) of the bob varies with its displacement \(x\) from the equilibrium position as shown in Fig. 4.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 508, 803, 797]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 818, 534, 836]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 798, 89]]<|/det|>
State how Fig. 4.2 shows that the motion of the pendulum is simple harmonic.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 164, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 195, 146, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 180, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 195, 761, 214]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 4.2 to determine the angular frequency \(\omega\) of the oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 368, 920, 387]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\omega =\) ................................................. \(\text{rad s}^{-1}\) [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 400, 183, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 400, 769, 419]]<|/det|>
The angular frequency \(\omega\) is related to the length \(L\) of the pendulum by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 422, 544, 456]]<|/det|>
\[\omega = \sqrt{\frac{k}{L}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 462, 376, 479]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 492, 774, 510]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in **(b)**(i) to determine \(k\). Give a unit with your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 666, 920, 684]]<|/det|>
<form>k = ..................................... unit ............. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 696, 146, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 696, 920, 730]]<|/det|>
While the pendulum is oscillating, the length of the string is increased in such a way that the total energy of the oscillations remains constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 742, 913, 760]]<|/det|>
Suggest and explain the qualitative effect of this change on the amplitude of the oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 863, 920, 881]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 866, 920, 885]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Fig. 5.1 shows four diodes and a load resistor of resistance \(1.2 \text{k}\Omega\), connected in a circuit that is used to produce rectification of an alternating voltage.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 128, 871, 303]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 320, 533, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 352, 144, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 180, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 351, 490, 370]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by rectification.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[851, 413, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 444, 181, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 444, 715, 463]]<|/det|>
State the type of rectification produced by the circuit in Fig. 5.1.
